article: I remember one Thanksgiving when our family had no money and no food, and someone came knocking on our door. A man was _ there with a huge box of food, a giant turkey and even some _ to cook it in. I couldn't _ it. My dad demanded, "Who are you? Where are you from?" The stranger announced, "I'm here because a friend of yours knows you're in need and that you wouldn't accept _ help, so I've brought this for you. Have a great Thanksgiving." My father said, "No, no, we can't accept this." The stranger replied, "You don't have a choice " , closed the door and left. Obviously that experience had a profound impact on my life. I _ myself that someday I would do well enough financially so that I could do the same thing for other people. By the time I was eighteen I had created my Thanksgiving ritual . I would go out _ and buy enough food for one or two _ . Then I would dress like a delivery boy, go to the _ neighborhood and just knock on a _ . I always _ a note that explained my Thanksgiving experience _ a kid. The note said, "All that I ask later is that you take good enough care of your family so that someday you can do the same thing for someone else." I have received more from this annual ritual than I have from any amount of _ I've ever earned. Years ago I was in New York City with my new wife during Thanksgiving. She was sad because we were not with our family. _ she would be home decorating the house for Christmas, but we were _ in a hotel room. When I told her what I always did on Thanksgiving, she got excited. We packed enough food for seven families for thirty days and went to buildings where half a dozen people lived in one room with no electricity and no heat in winter surrounded by rats, cockroaches and the smell of urine . It was both an _ realization that people lived in this way and a truly fulfilling experience to make even a small difference.
